This suggests there might be a problem with the `Role` object itself or how it's being handled. Let's fix this specific part of the code:

<augment_code_snippet path="mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/service/UserService.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
@Transactional
public User registerNewUser(UserRegistrationDto registrationDto) {
 // Check if username or email already exists
 if (userRepository.existsByUsername(registrationDto.getUsername())) {
 throw new RuntimeException("Username is already taken!");
 }

 if (userRepository.existsByEmail(registrationDto.getEmail())) {
 throw new RuntimeException("Email is already in use!");
 }

 // Create new user
 User user = User.builder()
 .username(registrationDto.getUsername())
 .email(registrationDto.getEmail())
 .password(passwordEncoder.encode(registrationDto.getPassword()))
 .firstName(registrationDto.getFirstName())
 .lastName(registrationDto.getLastName())
 .phoneNumber(registrationDto.getPhoneNumber())
 .isEnabled(true)
 .build();

 // Assign default role (USER)
 try {
 // First save the user without roles
 user = userRepository.save(user);
 
 // Then fetch the role and add it
 Role userRole = roleRepository.findByName("USER")
 .orElseThrow(() -> new RuntimeException("Default role not found."));
 
 // Create a new set and add the role
 Set<Role> roles = new HashSet<>();
 roles.add(userRole);
 
 // Set the roles and save again
 user.setRoles(roles);
 return userRepository.save(user);
 } catch (Exception e) {
 throw new RuntimeException("Error assigning role to user: " + e.getMessage(), e);
 }
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

Let's also fix the `Role` class constructor that's causing issues:

<augment_code_snippet path="mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/entity/Role.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
package com.mybank.common.entity;

import lombok.AllArgsConstructor;
import lombok.Builder;
import lombok.Data;
import lombok.NoArgsConstructor;

import jakarta.persistence.*;
import java.time.LocalDateTime;
import java.util.HashSet;
import java.util.Objects;
import java.util.Set;

@Entity
@Table(name = "ROLES")
@Data
@NoArgsConstructor
@AllArgsConstructor
@Builder
public class Role {

 @Id
 @GeneratedValue(strategy = GenerationType.IDENTITY)
 @Column(name = "role_id")
 private Long roleId;

 @Column(name = "name", nullable = false, unique = true, length = 50)
 private String name;

 @Column(name = "description", length = 255)
 private String description;

 @Column(name = "created_at", updatable = false)
 private LocalDateTime createdAt;

 @Column(name = "updated_at")
 private LocalDateTime updatedAt;

 @ManyToMany(mappedBy = "roles")
 private Set<User> users = new HashSet<>();

 // Fix the constructor that's causing issues
 public Role(String roleName) {
 this.name = roleName;
 }

 @PrePersist
 protected void onCreate() {
 this.createdAt = LocalDateTime.now();
 this.updatedAt = LocalDateTime.now();
 }

 @PreUpdate
 protected void onUpdate() {
 this.updatedAt = LocalDateTime.now();
 }

 @Override
 public boolean equals(Object o) {
 if (this == o) return true;
 if (o == null || getClass() != o.getClass()) return false;
 Role role = (Role) o;
 return Objects.equals(name, role.name);
 }

 @Override
 public int hashCode() {
 return Objects.hash(name);
 }
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

```java
// Add these methods to the User class

 this.roles = roles != null ? roles : new HashSet<>();
}

public Set<Role> getRoles() {
 if (this.roles == null) {
 this.roles = new HashSet<>();
 }
 return this.roles;
}

public void addRole(Role role) {
 if (this.roles == null) {
 this.roles = new HashSet<>();
 }
 this.roles.add(role);
}
```

```java
// Add this utility method to help debug role issues
public void debugRoles() {
 try {
 List<Role> allRoles = roleRepository.findAll();
 System.out.println("All roles in database:");
 for (Role role : allRoles) {
 System.out.println("Role: " + role.getName() + ", ID: " + role.getRoleId());
 }
 
 Optional<Role> userRole = roleRepository.findByName("USER");
 if (userRole.isPresent()) {
 System.out.println("USER role found with ID: " + userRole.get().getRoleId());
 } else {
 System.out.println("USER role not found in database!");
 }
 } catch (Exception e) {
 System.err.println("Error debugging roles: " + e.getMessage());
 e.printStackTrace();
 }
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

These changes should fix the `ConcurrentModificationException` by:

1. Properly implementing the `Role` constructor
2. Adding proper equals and hashCode methods to the `Role` class
3. Ensuring the `User` entity properly handles roles
4. Adding defensive programming to prevent null pointer exceptions
5. Adding a utility method to help debug role issues

After making these changes, restart your application and try registering a user again. The issue should be resolved.

If you're still experiencing issues, you might want to check if the "USER" role exists in your database. You can add a call to the `debugRoles()` method in a controller or during application startup to verify.

This suggests there might be a problem with the `Role` object itself or how it's being handled. Let's fix this specific part of the code:

````java path=mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/service/UserService.java mode=EDIT
@Transactional
public User registerNewUser(UserRegistrationDto registrationDto) {
 // Check if username or email already exists
 if (userRepository.existsByUsername(registrationDto.getUsername())) {
 throw new RuntimeException("Username is already taken!");
 }

 if (userRepository.existsByEmail(registrationDto.getEmail())) {
 throw new RuntimeException("Email is already in use!");
 }

 // Create new user
 User user = User.builder()
 .username(registrationDto.getUsername())
 .email(registrationDto.getEmail())
 .password(passwordEncoder.encode(registrationDto.getPassword()))
 .firstName(registrationDto.getFirstName())
 .lastName(registrationDto.getLastName())
 .phoneNumber(registrationDto.getPhoneNumber())
 .isEnabled(true)
 .build();

 // Assign default role (USER)
 try {
 // First save the user without roles
 user = userRepository.save(user);
 
 // Then fetch the role and add it
 Role userRole = roleRepository.findByName("USER")
 .orElseThrow(() -> new RuntimeException("Default role not found."));
 
 // Create a new set and add the role
 Set<Role> roles = new HashSet<>();
 roles.add(userRole);
 
 // Set the roles and save again
 user.setRoles(roles);
 return userRepository.save(user);
 } catch (Exception e) {
 throw new RuntimeException("Error assigning role to user: " + e.getMessage(), e);
 }
}
````

Let's also fix the `Role` class constructor that's causing issues:

````java path=mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/entity/Role.java mode=EDIT
package com.mybank.common.entity;

import lombok.AllArgsConstructor;
import lombok.Builder;
import lombok.Data;
import lombok.NoArgsConstructor;

import jakarta.persistence.*;
import java.time.LocalDateTime;
import java.util.HashSet;
import java.util.Objects;
import java.util.Set;

@Entity
@Table(name = "ROLES")
@Data
@NoArgsConstructor
@AllArgsConstructor
@Builder
public class Role {

 @Id
 @GeneratedValue(strategy = GenerationType.IDENTITY)
 @Column(name = "role_id")
 private Long roleId;

 @Column(name = "name", nullable = false, unique = true, length = 50)
 private String name;

 @Column(name = "description", length = 255)
 private String description;

 @Column(name = "created_at", updatable = false)
 private LocalDateTime createdAt;

 @Column(name = "updated_at")
 private LocalDateTime updatedAt;

 @ManyToMany(mappedBy = "roles")
 private Set<User> users = new HashSet<>();

 // Fix the constructor that's causing issues
 public Role(String roleName) {
 this.name = roleName;
 }

 @PrePersist
 protected void onCreate() {
 this.createdAt = LocalDateTime.now();
 this.updatedAt = LocalDateTime.now();
 }

 @PreUpdate
 protected void onUpdate() {
 this.updatedAt = LocalDateTime.now();
 }

 @Override
 public boolean equals(Object o) {
 if (this == o) return true;
 if (o == null || getClass() != o.getClass()) return false;
 Role role = (Role) o;
 return Objects.equals(name, role.name);
 }

 @Override
 public int hashCode() {
 return Objects.hash(name);
 }
}
````

Let's also ensure the `User` entity properly handles roles:

````java path=mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/entity/User.java mode=EDIT
// Add these methods to the User class
public void setRoles(Set<Role> roles) {
 this.roles = roles != null ? roles : new HashSet<>();
}

public Set<Role> getRoles() {
 if (this.roles == null) {
 this.roles = new HashSet<>();
 }
 return this.roles;
}

public void addRole(Role role) {
 if (this.roles == null) {
 this.roles = new HashSet<>();
 }
 this.roles.add(role);
}
````

````java path=mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/service/UserService.java mode=EDIT
// Add this utility method to help debug role issues
public void debugRoles() {
 try {
 List<Role> allRoles = roleRepository.findAll();
 System.out.println("All roles in database:");
 for (Role role : allRoles) {
 System.out.println("Role: " + role.getName() + ", ID: " + role.getRoleId());
 }
 
 Optional<Role> userRole = roleRepository.findByName("USER");
 if (userRole.isPresent()) {
 System.out.println("USER role found with ID: " + userRole.get().getRoleId());
 } else {
 System.out.println("USER role not found in database!");
 }
 } catch (Exception e) {
 System.err.println("Error debugging roles: " + e.getMessage());
 e.printStackTrace();
 }
}
````

These changes should fix the `ConcurrentModificationException` by:

1. Properly implementing the `Role` constructor
2. Adding proper equals and hashCode methods to the `Role` class
3. Ensuring the `User` entity properly handles roles
4. Adding defensive programming to prevent null pointer exceptions
5. Adding a utility method to help debug role issues

After making these changes, restart your application and try registering a user again. The issue should be resolved.

If you're still experiencing issues, you might want to check if the "USER" role exists in your database. You can add a call to the `debugRoles()` method in a controller or during application startup to verify.

Let's fix this issue in the `AuthController`:

<augment_code_snippet path="myaccounts/src/main/java/com/mybank/myaccounts/controller/AuthController.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
@PostMapping("/login")
public ResponseEntity<?> createAuthenticationToken(@RequestBody AuthRequest authRequest) throws Exception {
 try {
 authenticationManager.authenticate(
 new UsernamePasswordAuthenticationToken(authRequest.getUsername(), authRequest.getPassword())
 );
 } catch (BadCredentialsException e) {
 throw new Exception("Incorrect username or password", e);
 }

 // Get UserDetails from the service
 final UserDetails userDetails = userDetailsService.loadUserByUsername(authRequest.getUsername());
 
 // Instead of casting, fetch the user from the repository
 com.mybank.common.entity.User user = userService.getUserByUsername(authRequest.getUsername())
 .orElseThrow(() -> new Exception("User not found"));
 
 // Generate token using the user entity
 final String jwt = jwtTokenUtil.generateAccessToken(user);

 return ResponseEntity.ok(new AuthResponse(jwt));
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

This change avoids the casting issue by:

1. Getting the `UserDetails` from the service for authentication
2. Then separately fetching the actual `User` entity from the repository
3. Using the entity to generate the JWT token

Let's also make sure your `UserDetailsServiceImpl` is correctly implemented:

<augment_code_snippet path="mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/service/UserDetailsServiceImpl.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
package com.mybank.common.service;

import com.mybank.common.entity.User;
import com.mybank.common.repository.UserRepository;
import org.springframework.security.core.authority.SimpleGrantedAuthority;
import org.springframework.security.core.userdetails.UserDetails;
import org.springframework.security.core.userdetails.UserDetailsService;
import org.springframework.security.core.userdetails.UsernameNotFoundException;
import org.springframework.stereotype.Service;
import org.springframework.transaction.annotation.Transactional;

import java.time.LocalDateTime;
import java.util.List;
import java.util.stream.Collectors;

@Service
public class UserDetailsServiceImpl implements UserDetailsService {

 private final UserRepository userRepository;

 public UserDetailsServiceImpl(UserRepository userRepository) {
 this.userRepository = userRepository;
 }

 @Override
 @Transactional
 public UserDetails loadUserByUsername(String username) throws UsernameNotFoundException {
 User user = userRepository.findByUsername(username)
 .orElseThrow(() -> new UsernameNotFoundException("User not found with username: " + username));

 // Update last login time
 user.setLastLoginDate(LocalDateTime.now());
 userRepository.save(user);

 List<SimpleGrantedAuthority> authorities = user.getRoles().stream()
 .map(role -> new SimpleGrantedAuthority("ROLE_" + role.getName()))
 .collect(Collectors.toList());

 // Return Spring Security's User object, not your custom User entity
 return new org.springframework.security.core.userdetails.User(
 user.getUsername(),
 user.getPassword(),
 user.getIsEnabled(),
 true, // account non-expired
 true, // credentials non-expired
 true, // account non-locked
 authorities
 );
 }
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

This implementation ensures that:

1. The `UserDetailsServiceImpl` returns a Spring Security `User` object, not your custom `User` entity
2. The roles are properly converted to `SimpleGrantedAuthority` objects with the "ROLE_" prefix
3. The last login time is updated

With these changes, the casting error should be resolved. After making these changes, restart your application and try logging in again.

````java path=mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/service/UserDetailsServiceImpl.java mode=EDIT
package com.mybank.common.service;

import com.mybank.common.entity.User;
import com.mybank.common.repository.UserRepository;
import org.springframework.security.core.authority.SimpleGrantedAuthority;
import org.springframework.security.core.userdetails.UserDetails;
import org.springframework.security.core.userdetails.UserDetailsService;
import org.springframework.security.core.userdetails.UsernameNotFoundException;
import org.springframework.stereotype.Service;
import org.springframework.transaction.annotation.Transactional;

import java.time.LocalDateTime;
import java.util.List;
import java.util.stream.Collectors;

@Service
public class UserDetailsServiceImpl implements UserDetailsService {

 private final UserRepository userRepository;

 public UserDetailsServiceImpl(UserRepository userRepository) {
 this.userRepository = userRepository;
 }

 @Override
 @Transactional
 public UserDetails loadUserByUsername(String username) throws UsernameNotFoundException {
 User user = userRepository.findByUsername(username)
 .orElseThrow(() -> new UsernameNotFoundException("User not found with username: " + username));

 // Update last login time
 user.setLastLoginDate(LocalDateTime.now());
 userRepository.save(user);

 List<SimpleGrantedAuthority> authorities = user.getRoles().stream()
 .map(role -> new SimpleGrantedAuthority("ROLE_" + role.getName()))
 .collect(Collectors.toList());

 // Return Spring Security's User object, not your custom User entity
 return new org.springframework.security.core.userdetails.User(
 user.getUsername(),
 user.getPassword(),
 user.getIsEnabled(),
 true, // account non-expired
 true, // credentials non-expired
 true, // account non-locked
 authorities
 );
 }
}
````

This implementation ensures that:

1. The `UserDetailsServiceImpl` returns a Spring Security `User` object, not your custom `User` entity
2. The roles are properly converted to `SimpleGrantedAuthority` objects with the "ROLE_" prefix
3. The last login time is updated

With these changes, the casting error should be resolved. After making these changes, restart your application and try logging in again.

"}]}]},"mentioned_items":[],"structured_output_nodes":[{"id":0,"type":0,"content":"The error is occurring because the "roles" claim in your JWT token is null. Let's fix the `JwtRequestFilter` to handle this case properly:

<augment_code_snippet path="mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/security/JwtRequestFilter.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
private UserDetails getUserDetails(String token) {
 User userDetails = new User();
 Claims claims = jwtUtil.parseClaims(token);
 String subject = (String) claims.get(Claims.SUBJECT);
 
 // Get roles safely, handling null case
 String rolesString = (String) claims.get("roles");
 
 logger.debug("JWT Subject: {}", subject);
 logger.debug("JWT Roles: {}", rolesString);
 
 // Handle roles safely
 if (rolesString != null && !rolesString.isEmpty()) {
 rolesString = rolesString.replace("[", "").replace("]", "");
 String[] roleNames = rolesString.split(",");

 for (String aRoleName : roleNames) {
 aRoleName = aRoleName.trim();
 if (!aRoleName.isEmpty()) {
 userDetails.addRole(new Role(aRoleName));
 }
 }
 } else {
 // Add a default role if none is found
 logger.warn("No roles found in token, adding default USER role");
 userDetails.addRole(new Role("USER"));
 }

 // Parse subject safely
 if (subject != null && subject.contains(",")) {
 String[] jwtSubject = subject.split(",");
 if (jwtSubject.length >= 2) {
 try {
 userDetails.setUserId(Long.parseLong(jwtSubject[0]));
 userDetails.setEmail(jwtSubject[1]);
 } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
 logger.error("Error parsing user ID from token: {}", e.getMessage());
 // Set default values
 userDetails.setUserId(0L);
 userDetails.setEmail("unknown@example.com");
 }
 } else {
 logger.error("Invalid subject format in token");
 userDetails.setUserId(0L);
 userDetails.setEmail("unknown@example.com");
 }
 } else {
 logger.error("Subject is null or invalid in token");
 userDetails.setUserId(0L);
 userDetails.setEmail("unknown@example.com");
 }

 return userDetails;
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

Now, let's also fix the `JwtTokenUtil` to ensure it always includes the roles claim:

<augment_code_snippet path="mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/security/JwtTokenUtil.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
public String generateAccessToken(User user) {
 // Create a safe string representation of roles
 StringBuilder rolesBuilder = new StringBuilder();
 rolesBuilder.append("[");
 
 if (user.getRoles() != null && !user.getRoles().isEmpty()) {
 boolean first = true;
 for (Role role : user.getRoles()) {
 if (!first) {
 rolesBuilder.append(",");
 }
 rolesBuilder.append(role.getName());
 first = false;
 }
 } else {
 // Add default role if none exists
 rolesBuilder.append("USER");
 }
 
 rolesBuilder.append("]");
 
 return Jwts.builder()
 .setSubject(String.format("%s,%s", user.getUserId(), user.getEmail()))
 .setIssuer("com.mybank")
 .claim("roles", rolesBuilder.toString())
 .setIssuedAt(new Date())
 .setExpiration(new Date(System.currentTimeMillis() + EXPIRE_DURATION))
 .signWith(SignatureAlgorithm.HS256, SECRET_KEY)
 .compact();
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

Let's also add a debug endpoint to check the token contents:

<augment_code_snippet path="myaccounts/src/main/java/com/mybank/myaccounts/controller/DebugController.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
@GetMapping("/debug-token")
public Map<String, Object> debugToken(@RequestHeader(value = "Authorization", required = false) String authHeader) {
 Map<String, Object> response = new HashMap<>();
 
 if (authHeader != null && authHeader.startsWith("Bearer ")) {
 String token = authHeader.substring(7);
 try {
 // Get the JWT token util
 JwtTokenUtil jwtUtil = new JwtTokenUtil();
 
 // Parse the token
 Claims claims = jwtUtil.parseClaims(token);
 
 // Add claims to response
 response.put("subject", claims.getSubject());
 response.put("roles", claims.get("roles"));
 response.put("issuedAt", claims.getIssuedAt());
 response.put("expiration", claims.getExpiration());
 response.put("valid", jwtUtil.validateAccessToken(token));
 
 } catch (Exception e) {
 response.put("error", "Failed to parse token: " + e.getMessage());
 }
 } else {
 response.put("error", "No Authorization header or not a Bearer token");
 }
 
 return response;
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

Finally, let's update the `AuthController` to ensure roles are properly included in the token:

<augment_code_snippet path="myaccounts/src/main/java/com/mybank/myaccounts/controller/AuthController.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
@PostMapping("/login")
public ResponseEntity<?> createAuthenticationToken(@RequestBody AuthRequest authRequest) throws Exception {
 try {
 authenticationManager.authenticate(
 new UsernamePasswordAuthenticationToken(authRequest.getUsername(), authRequest.getPassword())
 );
 } catch (BadCredentialsException e) {
 throw new Exception("Incorrect username or password", e);
 }

 // Get the user from the repository
 com.mybank.common.entity.User user = userService.getUserByUsername(authRequest.getUsername())
 .orElseThrow(() -> new Exception("User not found"));
 
 // Ensure user has at least one role
 if (user.getRoles() == null || user.getRoles().isEmpty()) {
 // Add default USER role if no roles exist
 Role userRole = new Role("USER");
 Set<Role> roles = new HashSet<>();
 roles.add(userRole);
 user.setRoles(roles);
 }
 
 // Generate token using the user entity
 final String jwt = jwtTokenUtil.generateAccessToken(user);

 return ResponseEntity.ok(new AuthResponse(jwt));
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

These changes should fix the NullPointerException by:

1. Adding null checks for the roles claim in the JWT token
2. Ensuring the roles claim is always included in the token, even if the user has no roles
3. Adding a default role if none exists
4. Adding a debug endpoint to check the token contents

After making these changes, restart your application and try again. The issue should be resolved.

Let's fix the `JwtRequestFilter` to handle this case properly:

````java path=mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/security/JwtRequestFilter.java mode=EDIT
private UserDetails getUserDetails(String token) {
 User userDetails = new User();
 Claims claims = jwtUtil.parseClaims(token);
 String subject = (String) claims.get(Claims.SUBJECT);
 
 // Get roles safely, handling null case
 String rolesString = (String) claims.get("roles");
 
 logger.debug("JWT Subject: {}", subject);
 logger.debug("JWT Roles: {}", rolesString);
 
 // Handle roles safely
 if (rolesString != null && !rolesString.isEmpty()) {
 rolesString = rolesString.replace("[", "").replace("]", "");
 String[] roleNames = rolesString.split(",");

 for (String aRoleName : roleNames) {
 aRoleName = aRoleName.trim();
 if (!aRoleName.isEmpty()) {
 userDetails.addRole(new Role(aRoleName));
 }
 }
 } else {
 // Add a default role if none is found
 logger.warn("No roles found in token, adding default USER role");
 userDetails.addRole(new Role("USER"));
 }

 // Parse subject safely
 if (subject != null && subject.contains(",")) {
 String[] jwtSubject = subject.split(",");
 if (jwtSubject.length >= 2) {
 try {
 userDetails.setUserId(Long.parseLong(jwtSubject[0]));
 userDetails.setEmail(jwtSubject[1]);
 } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
 logger.error("Error parsing user ID from token: {}", e.getMessage());
 // Set default values
 userDetails.setUserId(0L);
 userDetails.setEmail("unknown@example.com");
 }
 } else {
 logger.error("Invalid subject format in token");
 userDetails.setUserId(0L);
 userDetails.setEmail("unknown@example.com");
 }
 } else {
 logger.error("Subject is null or invalid in token");
 userDetails.setUserId(0L);
 userDetails.setEmail("unknown@example.com");
 }

 return userDetails;
}
````

Now, let's also fix the `JwtTokenUtil` to ensure it always includes the roles claim:

````java path=mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/security/JwtTokenUtil.java mode=EDIT
public String generateAccessToken(User user) {
 // Create a safe string representation of roles
 StringBuilder rolesBuilder = new StringBuilder();
 rolesBuilder.append("[");
 
 if (user.getRoles() != null && !user.getRoles().isEmpty()) {
 boolean first = true;
 for (Role role : user.getRoles()) {
 if (!first) {
 rolesBuilder.append(",");
 }
 rolesBuilder.append(role.getName());
 first = false;
 }
 } else {
 // Add default role if none exists
 rolesBuilder.append("USER");
 }
 
 rolesBuilder.append("]");
 
 return Jwts.builder()
 .setSubject(String.format("%s,%s", user.getUserId(), user.getEmail()))
 .setIssuer("com.mybank")
 .claim("roles", rolesBuilder.toString())
 .setIssuedAt(new Date())
 .setExpiration(new Date(System.currentTimeMillis() + EXPIRE_DURATION))
 .signWith(SignatureAlgorithm.HS256, SECRET_KEY)
 .compact();
}
````

Let's also add a debug endpoint to check the token contents:

````java path=myaccounts/src/main/java/com/mybank/myaccounts/controller/DebugController.java mode=EDIT
@GetMapping("/debug-token")
public Map<String, Object> debugToken(@RequestHeader(value = "Authorization", required = false) String authHeader) {
 Map<String, Object> response = new HashMap<>();
 
 if (authHeader != null && authHeader.startsWith("Bearer ")) {
 String token = authHeader.substring(7);
 try {
 // Get the JWT token util
 JwtTokenUtil jwtUtil = new JwtTokenUtil();
 
 // Parse the token
 Claims claims = jwtUtil.parseClaims(token);
 
 // Add claims to response
 response.put("subject", claims.getSubject());
 response.put("roles", claims.get("roles"));
 response.put("issuedAt", claims.getIssuedAt());
 response.put("expiration", claims.getExpiration());
 response.put("valid", jwtUtil.validateAccessToken(token));
 
 } catch (Exception e) {
 response.put("error", "Failed to parse token: " + e.getMessage());
 }
 } else {
 response.put("error", "No Authorization header or not a Bearer token");
 }
 
 return response;
}
````

Finally, let's update the `AuthController` to ensure roles are properly included in the token:

````java path=myaccounts/src/main/java/com/mybank/myaccounts/controller/AuthController.java mode=EDIT
@PostMapping("/login")
public ResponseEntity<?> createAuthenticationToken(@RequestBody AuthRequest authRequest) throws Exception {
 try {
 authenticationManager.authenticate(
 new UsernamePasswordAuthenticationToken(authRequest.getUsername(), authRequest.getPassword())
 );
 } catch (BadCredentialsException e) {
 throw new Exception("Incorrect username or password", e);
 }

 // Get the user from the repository
 com.mybank.common.entity.User user = userService.getUserByUsername(authRequest.getUsername())
 .orElseThrow(() -> new Exception("User not found"));
 
 // Ensure user has at least one role
 if (user.getRoles() == null || user.getRoles().isEmpty()) {
 // Add default USER role if no roles exist
 Role userRole = new Role("USER");
 Set<Role> roles = new HashSet<>();
 roles.add(userRole);
 user.setRoles(roles);
 }
 
 // Generate token using the user entity
 final String jwt = jwtTokenUtil.generateAccessToken(user);

 return ResponseEntity.ok(new AuthResponse(jwt));
}
````

These changes should fix the NullPointerException by:

1. Adding null checks for the roles claim in the JWT token
2. Ensuring the roles claim is always included in the token, even if the user has no roles
3. Adding a default role if none exists
4. Adding a debug endpoint to check the token contents

After making these changes, restart your application and try again. The issue should be resolved.

attribute, like phone number?"}]}]},"mentioned_items":[],"structured_output_nodes":[{"id":0,"type":0,"content":"To include additional user attributes like phone number in the JWT token, you'll need to modify the token generation process in the `JwtTokenUtil` class. Here's how to do it:

<augment_code_snippet path="mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/security/JwtTokenUtil.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
public String generateAccessToken(User user) {
 // Create a safe string representation of roles
 StringBuilder rolesBuilder = new StringBuilder();
 rolesBuilder.append("[");
 
 if (user.getRoles() != null && !user.getRoles().isEmpty()) {
 boolean first = true;
 for (Role role : user.getRoles()) {
 if (!first) {
 rolesBuilder.append(",");
 }
 rolesBuilder.append(role.getName());
 first = false;
 }
 } else {
 // Add default role if none exists
 rolesBuilder.append("USER");
 }
 
 rolesBuilder.append("]");
 
 // Create a map for additional user attributes
 Map<String, Object> claims = new HashMap<>();
 claims.put("roles", rolesBuilder.toString());
 
 // Add user attributes to claims
 claims.put("firstName", user.getFirstName());
 claims.put("lastName", user.getLastName());
 claims.put("phoneNumber", user.getPhoneNumber());
 claims.put("userId", user.getUserId());
 
 return Jwts.builder()
 .setClaims(claims)
 .setSubject(String.format("%s,%s", user.getUserId(), user.getEmail()))
 .setIssuer("com.mybank")
 .setIssuedAt(new Date())
 .setExpiration(new Date(System.currentTimeMillis() + jwtExpiration * 1000))
 .signWith(secretKey)
 .compact();
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

Then, update the `AuthController` to return these additional attributes in the response:

<augment_code_snippet path="myaccounts/src/main/java/com/mybank/myaccounts/controller/AuthController.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
@PostMapping("/login")
public ResponseEntity<?> createAuthenticationToken(@RequestBody AuthRequest authRequest) throws Exception {
 try {
 authenticationManager.authenticate(
 new UsernamePasswordAuthenticationToken(authRequest.getUsername(), authRequest.getPassword())
 );
 } catch (BadCredentialsException e) {
 throw new Exception("Incorrect username or password", e);
 }

 // Get the user from the repository
 com.mybank.common.entity.User user = userService.getUserByUsername(authRequest.getUsername())
 .orElseThrow(() -> new Exception("User not found"));
 
 // Ensure user has at least one role
 if (user.getRoles() == null || user.getRoles().isEmpty()) {
 // Add default USER role if no roles exist
 Role userRole = new Role("USER");
 Set<Role> roles = new HashSet<>();
 roles.add(userRole);
 user.setRoles(roles);
 }
 
 // Generate token using the user entity
 final String jwt = jwtTokenUtil.generateAccessToken(user);

 // Create enhanced response with user details
 Map<String, Object> response = new HashMap<>();
 response.put("token", jwt);
 response.put("userId", user.getUserId());
 response.put("username", user.getUsername());
 response.put("email", user.getEmail());
 response.put("firstName", user.getFirstName());
 response.put("lastName", user.getLastName());
 response.put("phoneNumber", user.getPhoneNumber());
 
 // Add roles as a list
 List<String> roles = user.getRoles().stream()
 .map(Role::getName)
 .collect(Collectors.toList());
 response.put("roles", roles);

 return ResponseEntity.ok(response);
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

You'll also need to update the `AuthResponse` class to include these additional fields:

<augment_code_snippet path="mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/dto/AuthResponse.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
package com.mybank.common.dto;

import lombok.Data;
import java.util.List;

@Data
public class AuthResponse {
 private String token;
 private Long userId;
 private String username;
 private String email;
 private String firstName;
 private String lastName;
 private String phoneNumber;
 private List<String> roles;
 
 // Simple constructor for backward compatibility
 public AuthResponse(String token) {
 this.token = token;
 }
 
 // Full constructor
 public AuthResponse(String token, Long userId, String username, String email, 
 String firstName, String lastName, String phoneNumber, List<String> roles) {
 this.token = token;
 this.userId = userId;
 this.username = username;
 this.email = email;
 this.firstName = firstName;
 this.lastName = lastName;
 this.phoneNumber = phoneNumber;
 this.roles = roles;
 }
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

Finally, update the `JwtRequestFilter` to extract these additional claims when needed:

<augment_code_snippet path="mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/security/JwtRequestFilter.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
private UserDetails getUserDetails(String token) {
 User userDetails = new User();
 Claims claims = jwtUtil.parseClaims(token);
 
 // Extract subject
 String subject = (String) claims.get(Claims.SUBJECT);
 
 // Extract roles
 String rolesString = (String) claims.get("roles");
 
 // Extract additional user attributes
 String firstName = (String) claims.get("firstName");
 String lastName = (String) claims.get("lastName");
 String phoneNumber = (String) claims.get("phoneNumber");
 
 logger.debug("JWT Subject: {}", subject);
 logger.debug("JWT Roles: {}", rolesString);
 
 // Set additional user attributes
 userDetails.setFirstName(firstName);
 userDetails.setLastName(lastName);
 userDetails.setPhoneNumber(phoneNumber);
 
 // Handle roles safely
 if (rolesString != null && !rolesString.isEmpty()) {
 rolesString = rolesString.replace("[", "").replace("]", "");
 String[] roleNames = rolesString.split(",");

 for (String aRoleName : roleNames) {
 aRoleName = aRoleName.trim();
 if (!aRoleName.isEmpty()) {
 userDetails.addRole(new Role(aRoleName));
 }
 }
 } else {
 // Add a default role if none is found
 logger.warn("No roles found in token, adding default USER role");
 userDetails.addRole(new Role("USER"));
 }

 // Parse subject safely
 if (subject != null && subject.contains(",")) {
 String[] jwtSubject = subject.split(",");
 if (jwtSubject.length >= 2) {
 try {
 userDetails.setUserId(Long.parseLong(jwtSubject[0]));
 userDetails.setEmail(jwtSubject[1]);
 } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
 logger.error("Error parsing user ID from token: {}", e.getMessage());
 // Set default values
 userDetails.setUserId(0L);
 userDetails.setEmail("unknown@example.com");
 }
 } else {
 logger.error("Invalid subject format in token");
 userDetails.setUserId(0L);
 userDetails.setEmail("unknown@example.com");
 }
 } else {
 logger.error("Subject is null or invalid in token");
 userDetails.setUserId(0L);
 userDetails.setEmail("unknown@example.com");
 }

 return userDetails;
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

With these changes:

1. The JWT token will include additional user attributes like phone number
2. The login response will include both the token and user details
3. The filter will extract these additional attributes when processing requests

This approach gives you flexibility:
- The token itself contains the user attributes, so they can be extracted on the client side
- The login response includes both the token and the user details separately, making it easier for the client to use

After making these changes, restart your application and test the login endpoint. You should see the additional user attributes in both the token and the response.

myaccounts/mvnw:954-1599"}],"seen_state":"seen","structured_request_nodes":[{"id":0,"type":0,"text_node":{"content":"when people logged in correctly, how can I return the JWT token with a specific user's attribute, like phone number?"}},{"id":1,"type":4,"ide_state_node":{"workspaceFolders":[{"repositoryRoot":"D:/gzasc_workspace/mybank_workspace_shared","folderRoot":"D:/gzasc_workspace/mybank_workspace_shared"}],"workspaceFoldersUnchanged":false}}],"timestamp":"2025-05-28T11:49:11.357Z","response_text":"To include additional user attributes like phone number in the JWT token, you'll need to modify the token generation process in the `JwtTokenUtil` class. Here's how to do it:

````java path=mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/security/JwtTokenUtil.java mode=EDIT
public String generateAccessToken(User user) {
 // Create a safe string representation of roles
 StringBuilder rolesBuilder = new StringBuilder();
 rolesBuilder.append("[");
 
 if (user.getRoles() != null && !user.getRoles().isEmpty()) {
 boolean first = true;
 for (Role role : user.getRoles()) {
 if (!first) {
 rolesBuilder.append(",");
 }
 rolesBuilder.append(role.getName());
 first = false;
 }
 } else {
 // Add default role if none exists
 rolesBuilder.append("USER");
 }
 
 rolesBuilder.append("]");
 
 // Create a map for additional user attributes
 Map<String, Object> claims = new HashMap<>();
 claims.put("roles", rolesBuilder.toString());
 
 // Add user attributes to claims
 claims.put("firstName", user.getFirstName());
 claims.put("lastName", user.getLastName());
 claims.put("phoneNumber", user.getPhoneNumber());
 claims.put("userId", user.getUserId());
 
 return Jwts.builder()
 .setClaims(claims)
 .setSubject(String.format("%s,%s", user.getUserId(), user.getEmail()))
 .setIssuer("com.mybank")
 .setIssuedAt(new Date())
 .setExpiration(new Date(System.currentTimeMillis() + jwtExpiration * 1000))
 .signWith(secretKey)
 .compact();
}
````

Then, update the `AuthController` to return these additional attributes in the response:

````java path=myaccounts/src/main/java/com/mybank/myaccounts/controller/AuthController.java mode=EDIT
@PostMapping("/login")
public ResponseEntity<?> createAuthenticationToken(@RequestBody AuthRequest authRequest) throws Exception {
 try {
 authenticationManager.authenticate(
 new UsernamePasswordAuthenticationToken(authRequest.getUsername(), authRequest.getPassword())
 );
 } catch (BadCredentialsException e) {
 throw new Exception("Incorrect username or password", e);
 }

 // Get the user from the repository
 com.mybank.common.entity.User user = userService.getUserByUsername(authRequest.getUsername())
 .orElseThrow(() -> new Exception("User not found"));
 
 // Ensure user has at least one role
 if (user.getRoles() == null || user.getRoles().isEmpty()) {
 // Add default USER role if no roles exist
 Role userRole = new Role("USER");
 Set<Role> roles = new HashSet<>();
 roles.add(userRole);
 user.setRoles(roles);
 }
 
 // Generate token using the user entity
 final String jwt = jwtTokenUtil.generateAccessToken(user);

 // Create enhanced response with user details
 Map<String, Object> response = new HashMap<>();
 response.put("token", jwt);
 response.put("userId", user.getUserId());
 response.put("username", user.getUsername());
 response.put("email", user.getEmail());
 response.put("firstName", user.getFirstName());
 response.put("lastName", user.getLastName());
 response.put("phoneNumber", user.getPhoneNumber());
 
 // Add roles as a list
 List<String> roles = user.getRoles().stream()
 .map(Role::getName)
 .collect(Collectors.toList());
 response.put("roles", roles);

 return ResponseEntity.ok(response);
}
````

You'll also need to update the `AuthResponse` class to include these additional fields:

````java path=mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/dto/AuthResponse.java mode=EDIT
package com.mybank.common.dto;

import lombok.Data;
import java.util.List;

@Data
public class AuthResponse {
 private String token;
 private Long userId;
 private String username;
 private String email;
 private String firstName;
 private String lastName;
 private String phoneNumber;
 private List<String> roles;
 
 // Simple constructor for backward compatibility
 public AuthResponse(String token) {
 this.token = token;
 }
 
 // Full constructor
 public AuthResponse(String token, Long userId, String username, String email, 
 String firstName, String lastName, String phoneNumber, List<String> roles) {
 this.token = token;
 this.userId = userId;
 this.username = username;
 this.email = email;
 this.firstName = firstName;
 this.lastName = lastName;
 this.phoneNumber = phoneNumber;
 this.roles = roles;
 }
}
````

Finally, update the `JwtRequestFilter` to extract these additional claims when needed:

````java path=mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/security/JwtRequestFilter.java mode=EDIT
private UserDetails getUserDetails(String token) {
 User userDetails = new User();
 Claims claims = jwtUtil.parseClaims(token);
 
 // Extract subject
 String subject = (String) claims.get(Claims.SUBJECT);
 
 // Extract roles
 String rolesString = (String) claims.get("roles");
 
 // Extract additional user attributes
 String firstName = (String) claims.get("firstName");
 String lastName = (String) claims.get("lastName");
 String phoneNumber = (String) claims.get("phoneNumber");
 
 logger.debug("JWT Subject: {}", subject);
 logger.debug("JWT Roles: {}", rolesString);
 
 // Set additional user attributes
 userDetails.setFirstName(firstName);
 userDetails.setLastName(lastName);
 userDetails.setPhoneNumber(phoneNumber);
 
 // Handle roles safely
 if (rolesString != null && !rolesString.isEmpty()) {
 rolesString = rolesString.replace("[", "").replace("]", "");
 String[] roleNames = rolesString.split(",");

 for (String aRoleName : roleNames) {
 aRoleName = aRoleName.trim();
 if (!aRoleName.isEmpty()) {
 userDetails.addRole(new Role(aRoleName));
 }
 }
 } else {
 // Add a default role if none is found
 logger.warn("No roles found in token, adding default USER role");
 userDetails.addRole(new Role("USER"));
 }

 // Parse subject safely
 if (subject != null && subject.contains(",")) {
 String[] jwtSubject = subject.split(",");
 if (jwtSubject.length >= 2) {
 try {
 userDetails.setUserId(Long.parseLong(jwtSubject[0]));
 userDetails.setEmail(jwtSubject[1]);
 } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
 logger.error("Error parsing user ID from token: {}", e.getMessage());
 // Set default values
 userDetails.setUserId(0L);
 userDetails.setEmail("unknown@example.com");
 }
 } else {
 logger.error("Invalid subject format in token");
 userDetails.setUserId(0L);
 userDetails.setEmail("unknown@example.com");
 }
 } else {
 logger.error("Subject is null or invalid in token");
 userDetails.setUserId(0L);
 userDetails.setEmail("unknown@example.com");
 }

 return userDetails;
}
````

With these changes:

1. The JWT token will include additional user attributes like phone number
2. The login response will include both the token and user details
3. The filter will extract these additional attributes when processing requests

This approach gives you flexibility:
- The token itself contains the user attributes, so they can be extracted on the client side
- The login response includes both the token and the user details separately, making it easier for the client to use

After making these changes, restart your application and test the login endpoint. You should see the additional user attributes in both the token and the response.

```java
package com.mybank.mycards.repository;

import com.mybank.common.entity.Card;
import com.mybank.common.entity.CardTransaction;
import org.springframework.data.jpa.repository.JpaRepository;
import org.springframework.data.jpa.repository.Query;
import org.springframework.data.repository.query.Param;
import org.springframework.stereotype.Repository;

import java.time.LocalDateTime;
import java.util.List;

@Repository
public interface CardTransactionRepository extends JpaRepository<CardTransaction, Long> {

 // Find transactions by date range
 @Query("SELECT ct FROM CardTransaction ct WHERE ct.transactionDate BETWEEN :startDate AND :endDate")
 List<CardTransaction> findByUsernameAndTransactionDateBetween(
 @Param("startDate") LocalDateTime startDate,
 @Param("endDate") LocalDateTime endDate);
 
 // Find transactions by card and date range
 @Query("SELECT ct FROM CardTransaction ct WHERE ct.card = :card AND ct.transactionDate BETWEEN :startDate AND :endDate")
 List<CardTransaction> findByCardAndTransactionDateBetween(
 @Param("card") Card card,
 @Param("startDate") LocalDateTime startDate,
 @Param("endDate") LocalDateTime endDate);
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

```java
import org.springframework.boot.SpringApplication;
import org.springframework.boot.autoconfigure.SpringBootApplication;
import org.springframework.boot.autoconfigure.domain.EntityScan;
import org.springframework.context.annotation.ComponentScan;
import org.springframework.data.jpa.repository.config.EnableJpaRepositories;

@SpringBootApplication
@EntityScan(basePackages = {"com.mybank.common.entity"})
@ComponentScan(basePackages = {"com.mybank.mycards", "com.mybank.common.security", "com.mybank.common.config"})
@EnableJpaRepositories(basePackages = {"com.mybank.mycards.repository"})
public class MycardsApplication {

 public static void main(String[] args) {

 }
}
```

Now, let's update the `CardTransactionServiceImpl` to ensure it's properly using the repository:

<augment_code_snippet path="mycards/src/main/java/com/mybank/mycards/service/impl/CardTransactionServiceImpl.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
package com.mybank.mycards.service.impl;

import com.mybank.mycards.dto.CardTransactionDTO;
import com.mybank.common.entity.Card;
import com.mybank.common.entity.CardTransaction;
import com.mybank.mycards.mapper.CardTransactionMapper;
import com.mybank.mycards.repository.CardRepository;
import com.mybank.mycards.repository.CardTransactionRepository;
import com.mybank.mycards.service.ICardTransactionService;
import org.springframework.beans.factory.annotation.Autowired;
import org.springframework.stereotype.Service;
import org.springframework.transaction.annotation.Transactional;

import java.time.LocalDateTime;
import java.util.List;

@Service
public class CardTransactionServiceImpl implements ICardTransactionService {

 private final CardTransactionRepository cardTransactionRepository;
 private final CardRepository cardRepository;
 private final CardTransactionMapper cardTransactionMapper;

 @Autowired
 public CardTransactionServiceImpl(CardTransactionRepository cardTransactionRepository,
 CardRepository cardRepository,
 CardTransactionMapper cardTransactionMapper) {
 this.cardTransactionRepository = cardTransactionRepository;
 this.cardRepository = cardRepository;
 this.cardTransactionMapper = cardTransactionMapper;
 }

 @Override
 @Transactional
 public CardTransactionDTO createCardTransaction(CardTransactionDTO cardTransactionDTO) {
 // Find the card by ID or card number
 Card card = null;
 if (cardTransactionDTO.getCardId() != null) {
 card = cardRepository.findById(cardTransactionDTO.getCardId())
 .orElseThrow(() -> new RuntimeException("Card not found with ID: " + cardTransactionDTO.getCardId()));
 } else if (cardTransactionDTO.getCardNumber() != null) {
 card = cardRepository.findByCardNumber(cardTransactionDTO.getCardNumber())
 .orElseThrow(() -> new RuntimeException("Card not found with number: " + cardTransactionDTO.getCardNumber()));
 } else {
 throw new RuntimeException("Either card ID or card number must be provided");
 }

 // Convert DTO to entity
 CardTransaction transaction = cardTransactionMapper.toEntity(cardTransactionDTO);
 transaction.setCard(card);

 // Save the transaction
 CardTransaction savedTransaction = cardTransactionRepository.save(transaction);

 // Convert back to DTO
 return cardTransactionMapper.toDTO(savedTransaction);
 }

 @Override
 public List<CardTransaction> getTransactionsByUserAndDateRange(
 LocalDateTime startDate,
 LocalDateTime endDate) {

 return cardTransactionRepository.findByUsernameAndTransactionDateBetween(startDate, endDate);
 }

 @Override
 public CardTransactionDTO convertToDTO(CardTransaction transaction) {
 return cardTransactionMapper.toDTO(transaction);
 }

 @Override
 public List<CardTransaction> getTransactionsByCardNumberAndDateRange(
 String cardNumber, LocalDateTime startDate, LocalDateTime endDate) {
 
 // Find the card by card number
 Card card = cardRepository.findByCardNumber(cardNumber)
 .orElseThrow(() -> new RuntimeException("Card not found with number: " + cardNumber));
 
 // Use the repository to find transactions by card and date range
 return cardTransactionRepository.findByCardAndTransactionDateBetween(card, startDate, endDate);
 }
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

Let's also check the `CardTransaction` entity to ensure it's properly defined:

<augment_code_snippet path="mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/entity/CardTransaction.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
package com.mybank.common.entity;

import jakarta.persistence.*;
import lombok.AllArgsConstructor;
import lombok.Data;
import lombok.NoArgsConstructor;

import java.math.BigDecimal;
import java.time.LocalDateTime;

@Entity
@Table(name = "card_transactions")
@Data
@NoArgsConstructor
@AllArgsConstructor
public class CardTransaction {

 @Id
 @GeneratedValue(strategy = GenerationType.IDENTITY)
 private Long transactionId;

 @ManyToOne(fetch = FetchType.LAZY)
 @JoinColumn(name = "card_id", nullable = false)
 private Card card;

 @Column(nullable = false)
 private LocalDateTime transactionDate;

 @Column(nullable = false)
 private BigDecimal amount;

 @Column(length = 255)
 private String description;

 @Column(length = 50)
 private String merchantName;

 @Column(length = 50)
 private String transactionType;

 @Column(length = 50)
 private String status;
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

```java
@Configuration

public class RepositoryConfig {
 // This class explicitly enables JPA repositories in the specified package
}
```

1. Ensuring the `CardTransactionRepository` is properly annotated with `@Repository`
2. Adding `@EnableJpaRepositories` to the main application class
3. Creating a dedicated repository configuration class
4. Checking for potential conflicts with `CardRepository1`
5. Verifying the entity class is properly defined

After making these changes, restart your application. The bean should now be found and injected correctly.

````java path=mycards/src/main/java/com/mybank/mycards/repository/CardTransactionRepository.java mode=EDIT
package com.mybank.mycards.repository;

import com.mybank.common.entity.Card;
import com.mybank.common.entity.CardTransaction;
import org.springframework.data.jpa.repository.JpaRepository;
import org.springframework.data.jpa.repository.Query;
import org.springframework.data.repository.query.Param;
import org.springframework.stereotype.Repository;

import java.time.LocalDateTime;
import java.util.List;

@Repository
public interface CardTransactionRepository extends JpaRepository<CardTransaction, Long> {

 // Find transactions by date range
 @Query("SELECT ct FROM CardTransaction ct WHERE ct.transactionDate BETWEEN :startDate AND :endDate")
 List<CardTransaction> findByUsernameAndTransactionDateBetween(
 @Param("startDate") LocalDateTime startDate,
 @Param("endDate") LocalDateTime endDate);
 
 // Find transactions by card and date range
 @Query("SELECT ct FROM CardTransaction ct WHERE ct.card = :card AND ct.transactionDate BETWEEN :startDate AND :endDate")
 List<CardTransaction> findByCardAndTransactionDateBetween(
 @Param("card") Card card,
 @Param("startDate") LocalDateTime startDate,
 @Param("endDate") LocalDateTime endDate);
}
````

Now, let's update the `CardTransactionServiceImpl` to ensure it's properly using the repository:

````java path=mycards/src/main/java/com/mybank/mycards/service/impl/CardTransactionServiceImpl.java mode=EDIT
package com.mybank.mycards.service.impl;

import com.mybank.mycards.dto.CardTransactionDTO;
import com.mybank.common.entity.Card;
import com.mybank.common.entity.CardTransaction;
import com.mybank.mycards.mapper.CardTransactionMapper;
import com.mybank.mycards.repository.CardRepository;
import com.mybank.mycards.repository.CardTransactionRepository;
import com.mybank.mycards.service.ICardTransactionService;
import org.springframework.beans.factory.annotation.Autowired;
import org.springframework.stereotype.Service;
import org.springframework.transaction.annotation.Transactional;

import java.time.LocalDateTime;
import java.util.List;

@Service
public class CardTransactionServiceImpl implements ICardTransactionService {

 private final CardTransactionRepository cardTransactionRepository;
 private final CardRepository cardRepository;
 private final CardTransactionMapper cardTransactionMapper;

 @Autowired
 public CardTransactionServiceImpl(CardTransactionRepository cardTransactionRepository,
 CardRepository cardRepository,
 CardTransactionMapper cardTransactionMapper) {
 this.cardTransactionRepository = cardTransactionRepository;
 this.cardRepository = cardRepository;
 this.cardTransactionMapper = cardTransactionMapper;
 }

 @Override
 @Transactional
 public CardTransactionDTO createCardTransaction(CardTransactionDTO cardTransactionDTO) {
 // Find the card by ID or card number
 Card card = null;
 if (cardTransactionDTO.getCardId() != null) {
 card = cardRepository.findById(cardTransactionDTO.getCardId())
 .orElseThrow(() -> new RuntimeException("Card not found with ID: " + cardTransactionDTO.getCardId()));
 } else if (cardTransactionDTO.getCardNumber() != null) {
 card = cardRepository.findByCardNumber(cardTransactionDTO.getCardNumber())
 .orElseThrow(() -> new RuntimeException("Card not found with number: " + cardTransactionDTO.getCardNumber()));
 } else {
 throw new RuntimeException("Either card ID or card number must be provided");
 }

 // Convert DTO to entity
 CardTransaction transaction = cardTransactionMapper.toEntity(cardTransactionDTO);
 transaction.setCard(card);

 // Save the transaction
 CardTransaction savedTransaction = cardTransactionRepository.save(transaction);

 // Convert back to DTO
 return cardTransactionMapper.toDTO(savedTransaction);
 }

 @Override
 public List<CardTransaction> getTransactionsByUserAndDateRange(
 LocalDateTime startDate,
 LocalDateTime endDate) {

 return cardTransactionRepository.findByUsernameAndTransactionDateBetween(startDate, endDate);
 }

 @Override
 public CardTransactionDTO convertToDTO(CardTransaction transaction) {
 return cardTransactionMapper.toDTO(transaction);
 }

 @Override
 public List<CardTransaction> getTransactionsByCardNumberAndDateRange(
 String cardNumber, LocalDateTime startDate, LocalDateTime endDate) {
 
 // Find the card by card number
 Card card = cardRepository.findByCardNumber(cardNumber)
 .orElseThrow(() -> new RuntimeException("Card not found with number: " + cardNumber));
 
 // Use the repository to find transactions by card and date range
 return cardTransactionRepository.findByCardAndTransactionDateBetween(card, startDate, endDate);
 }
}
````

Let's also check the `CardTransaction` entity to ensure it's properly defined:

````java path=mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/entity/CardTransaction.java mode=EDIT
package com.mybank.common.entity;

import jakarta.persistence.*;
import lombok.AllArgsConstructor;
import lombok.Data;
import lombok.NoArgsConstructor;

import java.math.BigDecimal;
import java.time.LocalDateTime;

@Entity
@Table(name = "card_transactions")
@Data
@NoArgsConstructor
@AllArgsConstructor
public class CardTransaction {

 @Id
 @GeneratedValue(strategy = GenerationType.IDENTITY)
 private Long transactionId;

 @ManyToOne(fetch = FetchType.LAZY)
 @JoinColumn(name = "card_id", nullable = false)
 private Card card;

 @Column(nullable = false)
 private LocalDateTime transactionDate;

 @Column(nullable = false)
 private BigDecimal amount;

 @Column(length = 255)
 private String description;

 @Column(length = 50)
 private String merchantName;

 @Column(length = 50)
 private String transactionType;

 @Column(length = 50)
 private String status;
}
````

````java path=mycards/src/main/java/com/mybank/mycards/config/RepositoryConfig.java mode=EDIT
}
````

```java
package com.mybank.common.dto;

import jakarta.validation.constraints.Email;
import jakarta.validation.constraints.NotBlank;
import jakarta.validation.constraints.Pattern;
import jakarta.validation.constraints.Size;
import lombok.Data;

import java.util.Set;

@Data
public class UserRegistrationDto {
 @NotBlank(message = "Username is required")
 @Size(min = 3, max = 50, message = "Username must be between 3 and 50 characters")
 private String username;
 
 @NotBlank(message = "Email is required")
 @Email(message = "Email should be valid")
 private String email;
 
 @NotBlank(message = "Password is required")
 @Size(min = 6, message = "Password must be at least 6 characters")
 private String password;
 
 @NotBlank(message = "First name is required")
 private String firstName;
 
 @NotBlank(message = "Last name is required")
 private String lastName;
 
 @Pattern(regexp = "^\\+?[0-9]{10,15}$", message = "Phone number must be valid")
 private String phoneNumber;
 
 // Add roles field to store user roles
 private Set<String> roles;
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

Now, let's update the `UserService` to handle these roles during registration:

<augment_code_snippet path="mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/service/UserService.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
@Transactional
public User registerNewUser(UserRegistrationDto registrationDto) {
 // Check if username or email already exists
 if (userRepository.existsByUsername(registrationDto.getUsername())) {
 throw new RuntimeException("Username is already taken!");
 }

 if (userRepository.existsByEmail(registrationDto.getEmail())) {
 throw new RuntimeException("Email is already in use!");
 }

 // Create new user
 User user = User.builder()
 .username(registrationDto.getUsername())
 .email(registrationDto.getEmail())
 .password(passwordEncoder.encode(registrationDto.getPassword()))
 .firstName(registrationDto.getFirstName())
 .lastName(registrationDto.getLastName())
 .phoneNumber(registrationDto.getPhoneNumber())
 .isEnabled(true)
 .build();

 // First save the user without roles
 user = userRepository.save(user);
 
 // Create a new set for roles
 Set<Role> roles = new HashSet<>();
 
 // Check if roles were provided in the DTO
 if (registrationDto.getRoles() != null && !registrationDto.getRoles().isEmpty()) {
 // Add each role from the DTO
 for (String roleName : registrationDto.getRoles()) {
 Role role = roleRepository.findByName(roleName)
 .orElseThrow(() -> new RuntimeException("Role not found: " + roleName));
 roles.add(role);
 }
 } else {
 // If no roles provided, assign default USER role
 Role userRole = roleRepository.findByName("USER")
 .orElseThrow(() -> new RuntimeException("Default role not found."));
 roles.add(userRole);
 }
 
 // Set the roles and save again
 user.setRoles(roles);
 return userRepository.save(user);
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

Now, let's update the `SecurityConfig` to ensure the endpoint permissions are correctly set:

<augment_code_snippet path="mycards/src/main/java/com/mybank/mycards/config/SecurityConfig.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
@Bean
public SecurityFilterChain securityFilterChain(HttpSecurity http) throws Exception {
 http
 .cors(cors -> cors.configurationSource(corsConfigurationSource()))
 .csrf(csrf -> csrf.disable())
 .authorizeHttpRequests(auth -> auth
 .requestMatchers("/api/cards/public/**").permitAll()
 .requestMatchers("/api/public/**").permitAll()
 .requestMatchers("/error").permitAll()
 // Update this line to use hasAnyAuthority instead of hasAuthority
 .requestMatchers("/api/cards/transactions/recent-transactions").hasAnyAuthority("USER", "ADMIN", "MANAGER")
 .requestMatchers("/api/accounts/admin/**").hasAuthority("ADMIN")
 .anyRequest().authenticated()
 )
 .sessionManagement(session -> session
 .sessionCreationPolicy(SessionCreationPolicy.STATELESS)
 )
 .addFilterBefore(jwtRequestFilter, UsernamePasswordAuthenticationFilter.class);

 return http.build();
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

Let's also update the `JwtRequestFilter` to properly handle roles:

<augment_code_snippet path="mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/security/JwtRequestFilter.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
private UserDetails getUserDetails(String token) {
 User userDetails = new User();
 Claims claims = jwtUtil.parseClaims(token);
 
 // Extract subject
 String subject = (String) claims.get(Claims.SUBJECT);
 
 // Extract roles
 String rolesString = (String) claims.get("roles");
 
 // Extract additional user attributes
 String firstName = (String) claims.get("firstName");
 String lastName = (String) claims.get("lastName");
 String phoneNumber = (String) claims.get("phoneNumber");
 
 logger.debug("JWT Subject: {}", subject);
 logger.debug("JWT Roles: {}", rolesString);
 logger.debug("JWT Phone Number: {}", phoneNumber);
 
 // Set additional user attributes
 userDetails.setFirstName(firstName);
 userDetails.setLastName(lastName);
 userDetails.setPhoneNumber(phoneNumber);
 
 // Handle roles safely
 if (rolesString != null && !rolesString.isEmpty()) {
 rolesString = rolesString.replace("[", "").replace("]", "");
 String[] roleNames = rolesString.split(",");

 for (String aRoleName : roleNames) {
 aRoleName = aRoleName.trim();
 if (!aRoleName.isEmpty()) {
 userDetails.addRole(new Role(aRoleName));
 }
 }
 } else {
 // Add a default role if none is found
 logger.warn("No roles found in token, adding default USER role");
 userDetails.addRole(new Role("USER"));
 }

 // Parse subject safely
 if (subject != null && subject.contains(",")) {
 String[] jwtSubject = subject.split(",");
 if (jwtSubject.length >= 2) {
 try {
 userDetails.setUserId(Long.parseLong(jwtSubject[0]));
 userDetails.setEmail(jwtSubject[1]);
 } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
 logger.error("Error parsing user ID from token: {}", e.getMessage());
 // Set default values
 userDetails.setUserId(0L);
 userDetails.setEmail("unknown@example.com");
 }
 } else {
 logger.error("Invalid subject format in token");
 userDetails.setUserId(0L);
 userDetails.setEmail("unknown@example.com");
 }
 } else {
 logger.error("Subject is null or invalid in token");
 userDetails.setUserId(0L);
 userDetails.setEmail("unknown@example.com");
 }

 return userDetails;
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

Finally, let's update the `UserDetailsServiceImpl` to ensure roles are properly loaded:

<augment_code_snippet path="mybank-bom/common/src/main/java/com/mybank/common/service/UserDetailsServiceImpl.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
@Override
@Transactional
public UserDetails loadUserByUsername(String username) throws UsernameNotFoundException {
 User user = userRepository.findByUsername(username)
 .orElseThrow(() -> new UsernameNotFoundException("User not found with username: " + username));

 // Update last login time
 user.setLastLoginDate(LocalDateTime.now());
 userRepository.save(user);

 // Create authorities with both ROLE_ prefix and without prefix for flexibility
 List<SimpleGrantedAuthority> authorities = new ArrayList<>();
 
 for (Role role : user.getRoles()) {
 // Add with ROLE_ prefix for hasRole() method
 authorities.add(new SimpleGrantedAuthority("ROLE_" + role.getName()));
 // Add without prefix for hasAuthority() method
 authorities.add(new SimpleGrantedAuthority(role.getName()));
 }
 
 return new org.springframework.security.core.userdetails.User(
 user.getUsername(),
 user.getPassword(),
 user.getIsEnabled(),
 true, true, true,
 authorities);
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

These changes will:

1. Add a `roles` field to the `UserRegistrationDto` to allow specifying roles during registration
2. Update the `UserService` to handle these roles when registering a new user
3. Modify the security configuration to use `hasAnyAuthority` for more flexibility
4. Update the JWT filter to properly extract and handle roles
5. Ensure the `UserDetailsServiceImpl` adds authorities both with and without the `ROLE_` prefix

After making these changes, restart your application and try accessing the endpoint again. The 403 error should be resolved if the user has the appropriate role.

Please contact support [here](https://docs.augmentcode.com/troubleshooting/support) for more information.*","workspace_file_chunks":[]},{"status":"success","request_id":"4e7bcbd8-8817-460f-80f5-7e9027095a0c","request_message":"I need a method in UserRepoistory of BankDesk to list all users whose customerId is null and USER is in his roles ","rich_text_json_repr":{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I need a method in UserRepoistory of BankDesk to list all users whose customerId is null and USER is in his roles "}]}]},"mentioned_items":[],"structured_output_nodes":[{"id":0,"type":0,"content":"Let's add the required method to the `UserRepository` in the BankDesk module. This method will find all users who have a null `customerId` and have the "USER" role:

<augment_code_snippet path="bankdesk/src/main/java/com/mybank/bankdesk/repoistory/UserRepository.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
package com.mybank.bankdesk.repoistory;

import org.springframework.data.jpa.repository.JpaRepository;
import org.springframework.data.jpa.repository.Query;
import org.springframework.stereotype.Repository;
import com.mybank.common.entity.User;

import java.util.List;

@Repository
public interface UserRepository extends JpaRepository<User,Long> {
 
 /**
 * Find all users who have a null customerId and have the USER role
 * 
 * @return List of users with null customerId and USER role
 */
 @Query("SELECT u FROM User u JOIN u.roles r WHERE u.customer.customerId IS NULL AND r.name = 'USER'")
 List<User> findUsersWithNullCustomerIdAndUserRole();
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

This query uses JPQL to:
1. Join the `User` entity with its `roles` collection
2. Filter for users where `customer.customerId` is null
3. Filter for users who have a role with the name "USER"

You can now use this method in your service layer to retrieve the list of users who meet these criteria. For example:

<augment_code_snippet path="bankdesk/src/main/java/com/mybank/bankdesk/service/UserService.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
package com.mybank.bankdesk.service;

import com.mybank.bankdesk.repoistory.UserRepository;
import com.mybank.common.entity.User;
import org.springframework.beans.factory.annotation.Autowired;
import org.springframework.stereotype.Service;

import java.util.List;

@Service
public class UserService {

 private final UserRepository userRepository;

 @Autowired
 public UserService(UserRepository userRepository) {
 this.userRepository = userRepository;
 }

 /**
 * Get all users who have a null customerId and have the USER role
 * 
 * @return List of users with null customerId and USER role
 */
 public List<User> getUsersWithNullCustomerIdAndUserRole() {
 return userRepository.findUsersWithNullCustomerIdAndUserRole();
 }
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

And you can expose this functionality through a controller:

<augment_code_snippet path="bankdesk/src/main/java/com/mybank/bankdesk/controller/UserController.java" mode="EDIT">
```java
package com.mybank.bankdesk.controller;

import com.mybank.bankdesk.service.UserService;
import com.mybank.common.entity.User;
import org.springframework.beans.factory.annotation.Autowired;
import org.springframework.http.ResponseEntity;
import org.springframework.security.access.prepost.PreAuthorize;
import org.springframework.web.bind.annotation.GetMapping;
import org.springframework.web.bind.annotation.RequestMapping;
import org.springframework.web.bind.annotation.RestController;

import java.util.List;

@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api/bankdesk/users")
public class UserController {

 private final UserService userService;

 @Autowired
 public UserController(UserService userService) {
 this.userService = userService;
 }

 /**
 * Get all users who have a null customerId and have the USER role
 * This endpoint is restricted to users with ADMIN role
 * 
 * @return List of users with null customerId and USER role
 */
 @GetMapping("/unassigned")
 @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN')")
 public ResponseEntity<List<User>> getUnassignedUsers() {
 List<User> users = userService.getUsersWithNullCustomerIdAndUserRole();
 return ResponseEntity.ok(users);
 }
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

This implementation:
1. Creates a repository method to find users with null customerId and USER role
2. Wraps this in a service method for business logic
3. Exposes the functionality through a REST endpoint that's secured with `@PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN')")`

The endpoint will be accessible at `/api/bankdesk/users/unassigned` and will return a list of users who meet the criteria.

This method will find all users who have a null `customerId` and have the "USER" role:

````java path=bankdesk/src/main/java/com/mybank/bankdesk/repoistory/UserRepository.java mode=EDIT
package com.mybank.bankdesk.repoistory;

import org.springframework.data.jpa.repository.JpaRepository;
import org.springframework.data.jpa.repository.Query;
import org.springframework.stereotype.Repository;
import com.mybank.common.entity.User;

import java.util.List;

@Repository
public interface UserRepository extends JpaRepository<User,Long> {
 
 /**
 * Find all users who have a null customerId and have the USER role
 * 
 * @return List of users with null customerId and USER role
 */
 @Query("SELECT u FROM User u JOIN u.roles r WHERE u.customer.customerId IS NULL AND r.name = 'USER'")
 List<User> findUsersWithNullCustomerIdAndUserRole();
}
````

This query uses JPQL to:
1. Join the `User` entity with its `roles` collection
2. Filter for users where `customer.customerId` is null
3. Filter for users who have a role with the name "USER"

You can now use this method in your service layer to retrieve the list of users who meet these criteria. For example:

````java path=bankdesk/src/main/java/com/mybank/bankdesk/service/UserService.java mode=EDIT
package com.mybank.bankdesk.service;

import com.mybank.bankdesk.repoistory.UserRepository;
import com.mybank.common.entity.User;
import org.springframework.beans.factory.annotation.Autowired;
import org.springframework.stereotype.Service;

import java.util.List;

@Service
public class UserService {

 private final UserRepository userRepository;

 @Autowired
 public UserService(UserRepository userRepository) {
 this.userRepository = userRepository;
 }

 /**
 * Get all users who have a null customerId and have the USER role
 * 
 * @return List of users with null customerId and USER role
 */
 public List<User> getUsersWithNullCustomerIdAndUserRole() {
 return userRepository.findUsersWithNullCustomerIdAndUserRole();
 }
}
````

And you can expose this functionality through a controller:

````java path=bankdesk/src/main/java/com/mybank/bankdesk/controller/UserController.java mode=EDIT
package com.mybank.bankdesk.controller;

import com.mybank.bankdesk.service.UserService;
import com.mybank.common.entity.User;
import org.springframework.beans.factory.annotation.Autowired;
import org.springframework.http.ResponseEntity;
import org.springframework.security.access.prepost.PreAuthorize;
import org.springframework.web.bind.annotation.GetMapping;
import org.springframework.web.bind.annotation.RequestMapping;
import org.springframework.web.bind.annotation.RestController;

import java.util.List;

@RestController
@RequestMapping("/api/bankdesk/users")
public class UserController {

 private final UserService userService;

 @Autowired
 public UserController(UserService userService) {
 this.userService = userService;
 }

 /**
 * Get all users who have a null customerId and have the USER role
 * This endpoint is restricted to users with ADMIN role
 * 
 * @return List of users with null customerId and USER role
 */
 @GetMapping("/unassigned")
 @PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN')")
 public ResponseEntity<List<User>> getUnassignedUsers() {
 List<User> users = userService.getUsersWithNullCustomerIdAndUserRole();
 return ResponseEntity.ok(users);
 }
}
````

This implementation:
1. Creates a repository method to find users with null customerId and USER role
2. Wraps this in a service method for business logic
3. Exposes the functionality through a REST endpoint that's secured with `@PreAuthorize("hasRole('ADMIN')")`

The endpoint will be accessible at `/api/bankdesk/users/unassigned` and will return a list of users who meet the criteria.

```java
package com.mybank.bankdesk.service;

import com.mybank.bankdesk.dto.UserToCustomerRequest;
import com.mybank.bankdesk.repoistory.CustomerRepository;
import com.mybank.bankdesk.repoistory.UserRepository;
import com.mybank.common.entity.Customer;
import com.mybank.common.entity.User;
import org.springframework.beans.factory.annotation.Autowired;
import org.springframework.stereotype.Service;
import org.springframework.transaction.annotation.Transactional;

import java.time.LocalDateTime;
import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.List;
import java.util.Map;

@Service
public class UserService {

 private final UserRepository userRepository;
 private final CustomerRepository customerRepository;

 @Autowired
 public UserService(UserRepository userRepository, CustomerRepository customerRepository) {
 this.userRepository = userRepository;
 this.customerRepository = customerRepository;
 }

 /**
 * Get all users who have a null customerId and have the USER role
 * 
 * @return List of users with null customerId and USER role
 */
 public List<User> getUsersWithNullCustomerIdAndUserRole() {
 return userRepository.findUsersWithNullCustomerIdAndUserRole();
 }
 
 /**
 * Convert users to customers and update user records with customer IDs
 * 
 * @param request The request containing user IDs to convert
 * @return Map of user IDs to their corresponding customer IDs
 */
 @Transactional
 public Map<Long, Long> convertUsersToCustomers(UserToCustomerRequest request) {
 List<Long> userIds = request.getUserIds();
 Map<Long, Long> userToCustomerMap = new HashMap<>();
 
 // Fetch all users by their IDs
 List<User> users = userRepository.findAllById(userIds);
 
 // Create customers from users
 List<Customer> newCustomers = new ArrayList<>();
 for (User user : users) {
 // Skip if user already has a customer
 if (user.getCustomer() != null) {
 continue;
 }
 
 // Create new customer from user data
 Customer customer = new Customer();
 customer.setFirstName(user.getFirstName());
 customer.setLastName(user.getLastName());
 customer.setEmail(user.getEmail());
 customer.setPhoneNumber(user.getPhoneNumber());
 customer.setIsActive(true);
 customer.setCreatedAt(LocalDateTime.now());
 customer.setUpdatedAt(LocalDateTime.now());
 
 newCustomers.add(customer);
 }
 
 // Save all customers at once
 List<Customer> savedCustomers = customerRepository.saveAll(newCustomers);
 
 // Update users with customer IDs
 for (int i = 0; i < users.size(); i++) {
 if (i < savedCustomers.size()) {
 User user = users.get(i);
 Customer customer = savedCustomers.get(i);
 
 // Update user with customer reference
 user.setCustomer(customer);
 User updatedUser = userRepository.save(user);
 
 // Add to result map
 userToCustomerMap.put(updatedUser.getUserId(), customer.getCustomerId());
 }
 }
 
 return userToCustomerMap;
 }
}
```
</augment_code_snippet>

```java
 return ResponseEntity.ok(userToCustomerMap);
 }

 }
```
 
````java path=bankdesk/src/main/java/com/mybank/bankdesk/service/UserService.java mode=EDIT
 /**

 // Skip if user already has a customer
 if (user.getCustomer() != null) {
 continue;
 }
 
 // Create new customer from user data
 Customer customer = new Customer();
 customer.setFirstName(user.getFirstName());
 customer.setLastName(user.getLastName());
 customer.setEmail(user.getEmail());
 customer.setPhoneNumber(user.getPhoneNumber());
 customer.setIsActive(true);
 customer.setCreatedAt(LocalDateTime.now());
 customer.setUpdatedAt(LocalDateTime.now());
 
 newCustomers.add(customer);
 }
 
 // Save all customers at once
 List<Customer> savedCustomers = customerRepository.saveAll(newCustomers);
 
 // Update users with customer IDs
 for (int i = 0; i < users.size(); i++) {
 if (i < savedCustomers.size()) {
 User user = users.get(i);
 Customer customer = savedCustomers.get(i);
 
 // Update user with customer reference
 user.setCustomer(customer);
 User updatedUser = userRepository.save(user);
 
 // Add to result map
 userToCustomerMap.put(updatedUser.getUserId(), customer.getCustomerId());
 }
 }
 
 return userToCustomerMap;
 }
}
````
